snippet: The dearth of candidate visits to Dixville Notch is one more way in which New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary is seeing some of its cherished grass-roots traditions shaken up.
abstract: Dixville Notch, village in New Hampshire village traditionally visited by campaigning presidential candidates, is passed over by all but Gov John Kasich in 2016 race; resort hotel where nine residents of Dixville Notch cast their votes at midnight has closed for renovations, while candidates increasingly use national exposure like televised debates to garner attention.
lead_paragraph: The dearth of candidate visits to Dixville Notch is one more way in which New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary is seeing some of its cherished grass-roots traditions shaken up.

headline.main: New Hampshire’s First 9 Voters See Spotlight Slip Away
headline.print_headline: New Hampshire’s First 9 Voters See Spotlight Slip Away
